content: # Analog Multimeter Testing Guide for Older Boilers

This guide provides comprehensive instructions for using analog (non-digital) multimeters to test components in traditional non-condensing boilers. It covers proper meter setup, testing procedures, and interpretation of readings.
- **Scale Plate**: Displays readings with multiple calibrated scales
- **Pointer**: Needle that indicates readings on scales
- **Range Selector**: Rotary switch to select function and measurement range
- **Zero Adjust**: Screw to center pointer to zero
- **Ohms Adjust**: Control to calibrate for resistance measurements
- **Resistance (Ω)**: Multiple ranges (typically x1, x10, x100, x1k, x10k)
- **Continuity**: Uses resistance function at lowest range
- **Non-linear Scales**: Compressed at high end (resistance, AC voltage)
- **Mirrored Scale**: Helps avoid parallax error (reading from an angle)
- **Multipliers**: Readings must be multiplied by range setting
- Set range selector to any DC voltage range
- Adjust zero screw until pointer aligns exactly with zero on DC scale
- Repeat if meter is bumped or moved
- Set range selector to desired Ω range (start with x1)
- Connect red and black leads together
- Adjust "Ohms Adjust" knob until pointer reads exactly zero on the Ω scale
- Repeat this procedure each time you change resistance range
- Visually inspect leads for damaged insulation
- Check for loose connections at meter terminals
- Test continuity of leads using resistance range
- Never measure resistance in a powered circuit
- Use appropriate voltage range when measuring unknown voltages
- Always connect meter in parallel for voltage measurements
- Always connect meter in series for current measurements
- Keep hands away from metal probe tips when testing
- Analog multimeter with millivolt DC range (0-50mV or 0-100mV)
- Ensure pilot is lit and has been running for 5 minutes
- Set multimeter to lowest DC voltage range (typically 0-1V)
- Note: For most thermocouples, you'll be reading 25-30mV
- Connect black lead to outer shell (body) of thermocouple
- Connect red lead to center contact of thermocouple
- Read DC millivolts on appropriate scale
- Multiply by range setting if necessary
- Standard reading: 25-30mV for properly functioning thermocouple
- If reading is normal but boiler still fails: Problem likely in gas valve
- Turn off gas supply and disconnect power
- Set multimeter to appropriate resistance range (typically Ω x10 or x100)
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
- Infinite resistance (no movement): Open circuit, replace valve
- Very low resistance (near zero): Shorted coil, replace valve
- Within specification: Solenoid is electrically functional
- Analog multimeter with resistance and AC voltage functions
- Specification for motor resistance and voltage
- Set multimeter to appropriate AC voltage range (typically 0-250V)
- With power on, measure voltage at motor terminals
- Set multimeter to appropriate resistance range (typically Ω x10)
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
- Set multimeter to highest resistance range (Ω x10k)
- Connect one lead to motor terminal and one to motor case
- Normal reading: Infinite resistance (no needle movement)
- Analog multimeter with voltage and resistance functions
- Set to appropriate AC voltage range (typically 0-50V for secondary)
- Normal reading: 24V AC for control circuits
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
## PART 4: TESTING BOILER SENSORS AND SWITCHES
- Set multimeter to appropriate resistance range
- For NTC thermistors, typically use Ω x100 or x1k
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
- Compare with manufacturer's specifications for the ambient temperature
- If substantially different from specification: Replace sensor
- If resistance doesn't change with temperature: Replace sensor
- Set multimeter to lowest resistance range (Ω x1)
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
- Switch should change from infinite to zero resistance (or vice versa)
- No change when activated: Failed switch
- Incorrect starting state: Incorrect pressure or failed switch
- Set multimeter to lowest resistance range (Ω x1)
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
- Connect leads to limit stat terminals
- Normal temperature: Should read zero resistance (full deflection)
- When heated above limit: Should read infinite resistance (no movement)
- Note: Never bypass limit stats - they are critical safety devices
- Analog multimeter with resistance and AC voltage functions
- Set multimeter to appropriate AC voltage range
- Measure input voltage to ignition unit
- Normally 230V AC or 24V AC depending on system
- Set multimeter to appropriate resistance range
- Test primary winding according to manufacturer's specifications
- Never test secondary (high voltage) output with a multimeter
- Observe spark visually with proper safety precautions
- Analog multimeter with DC microamp range (if available)
- Boiler must be running with flame established
- Set multimeter to DC microamp range (if available)
- If no microamp range, use lowest DC voltage range
- Break the circuit at the flame detection wire
- Connect meter in series (+ to control, - to electrode)
- Read DC microamps on appropriate scale
- Below minimum: Clean flame rod, check placement
- No reading: Check electrode, wiring, control module
- Analog multimeter with resistance and AC voltage functions
- Set multimeter to appropriate AC voltage range (typically 0-250V)
- Set multimeter to appropriate resistance range
- Infinite resistance: Open circuit, replace pump
- Very low resistance: Possible short, replace pump
### Resistance Testing of Diverter Valve Coil
- Set multimeter to appropriate resistance range (typically Ω x10)
- Calibrate meter by zeroing with leads touched together
- Connect leads to valve coil terminals
- Infinite resistance: Open circuit, replace valve
- Very low resistance: Shorted coil, replace valve
- Within specification: Coil is electrically functional
- Position eyes directly above the pointer
- Keep meter on flat, stable surface
- Start with highest range when measuring unknown values
- Reduce range until pointer shows 1/3 to 2/3 scale deflection
- More accurate readings are obtained in the middle portion of scale
- For voltage/current: Multiply scale reading by range setting
- For resistance: Multiply by range factor (x1, x10, etc.)
- Example: Reading of 4.5 on 10V range = 4.5 volts
- Example: Reading of 20 on Ω x100 range = 2000 ohms
- Always isolate power before resistance testing
- Reconnect ground connections before restoring power
- Never bypass safety controls for testing
- Use proper range to avoid meter damage
- Allow cold sensors to reach ambient temperature before testing
- Shield meter from strong electromagnetic fields
- Avoid testing in very humid conditions
- Compare with known good components when possible
- Consider rate of change for temperature sensors
### Common Resistance Values for Boiler Components
| Gas Valve Solenoid | 40-400Ω | Varies by manufacturer |
| Fan Motor Windings | 20-80Ω | Varies by motor type |
| Ignition Transformer Primary | 2-20Ω | Secondary not measurable |
| Pump Motor | 20-100Ω | Varies by pump type |
| Limit Stat (normal) | <1Ω | Should read zero resistance |
| Pressure Switch (normal) | Varies | Depends on switch type |
| Diverter Valve Coil | 2-5kΩ | Higher when cold |
| Component to Test | Function | Range | Notes |
| Mains Voltage | AC Volts | 0-250V | Safety first! |
| Control Voltage | AC Volts | 0-50V | Secondary voltage |
| Thermocouple | DC Volts | 0-1V | Reading will be in mV |
| Flame Signal | DC μA | 0-50μA | If available |
| Gas Valve Coil | Ohms | x10 | Zero meter first |
| NTC Sensors | Ohms | x1k | Zero meter first |
| Limit Controls | Ohms | x1 | Zero meter first |
| Motor Windings | Ohms | x10 | Zero meter first |
| Fuses | Ohms | x1 | Zero meter first |
| PCB Relays | Ohms | x1 | Zero meter first |
- Replace internal battery when unable to zero resistance scale
- Typically uses 1.5V battery for resistance measurements
- Store with range set to high voltage position to avoid battery drain
- Calibrate resistance range before each measurement
- Periodically check accuracy against known voltage source
- Professional calibration recommended annually for critical work
- Always connect to highest range first
- Keep hands away from probe tips
- Use one hand when possible to avoid cross-body current path
- Verify meter and leads are rated for voltage being measured
- Never measure resistance on live circuits
- Set to appropriate function before connecting
- Disconnect leads when not in use
- Turn off gas supply before electrical testing
- Reconnect all safety devices before operation
- Refer to qualified engineers for complex issues
- Follow regulatory requirements for gas work
- Use proper tools for the job
- When in doubt, don't guess - verify
